context: Indirectly, however, NO causes an overall “slow-to-fast” shift characterized, in part, by increases in the rate of force development, maximal shortening velocity, and maximal power of both single muscle fibers and isolated muscles of animals. These indirect effects of NO are the result of activation of soluble guanylyl cyclase (sGC) and thus enhanced production of cyclic GMP (cGMP). Whether NO similarly influences the contractile properties of human muscle, however, has not been firmly established. In this context, the physiological effects of dietary nitrate (NO3 −) are of considerable interest. It is now recognized that, rather than simply being metabolically inert or, worse, a potential carcinogen, NO3 − in the diet is a significant source of NO in the body (cf. Refs. [8–12] for review).

This suggests a direct relationship between dietary nitrate and its conversion to NO, which influences muscle function.
